Sinus Anatomy
The paranasal sinuses extend into each nostril through which they drain via the anterior ethmoidal cellophane duct system to enter the inferior meatus where drainage continues toward the middle ear. The three paired sinuses include frontal sinuses, sphenoid sinuses,and ethmoid sinus.
Frontal Sinuses
Located between the eyebrows behind the eyes, the frontal sinus sits above the eyes and contains air connected directly to the external environment by small ostia located along its superior border. These ostia open onto the orbital cavity posteriorly and connect to the lacrimal sac below. They communicate with the internal carotid artery via openings called the cribriform plate. The bony floor of the frontal fossa forms the roof of these sinuses while their walls consist of thin perforated bones known as falx cerebri (or sella turcica ).
Sphenoid Sinuses __________________________________________________________________________________________
Situated behind the brain and situated deep within the skull base, the sphenoidal sinuses lie adjacent to several cranial nerves including the olfactory nerve, optic nerve, and trigeminal nerve. Like the frontal bone, the thickened portion of the spheroidal shape of the vertebral column serves as the primary wall separating the sphincteric membrane surrounding the sinuses from the rest of the cranium. This membrane prevents entry of extraneous material like bacteria, viruses, etc., thereby reducing the risk of contamination of the central nervous system. In addition to being anatomically isolated from the nasal cavities, the sigmoid sinuas form a complex network of interconnected sinuses. Three main subunits make up this intricate structure consisting of the greater wing sphenosynovial recess, lesser wing spenosternal recess, and lesser wing scaphoid recess. While many structures pass near the spongiosa, the greatest vessels entering the spinocerebellar tracts run across the lesser wings while those reaching the cavernous sinuses cross over the medial wing. The petrous portions of the temporal lobes sit close to the lesser wing retromastoid recess resulting in occasional communication of these regions during development.
Ethmoid Sinus ____________________________________________________________________________________________________
Situating just lateral to the frontal and sphenoids, the ethmoids occupy approximately 40 percent of the total volume of the maxillaries. Consisting primarily of hyaline cartilage lined by stratified squamous epithelium, these sinus serve both functional and structural roles. Functionally speaking, the majority of the space enclosed by the ethmidals houses secretory cells responsible for producing mucus containing antimicrobial proteins designed to protect against pathogens. As far as structural importance goes, these tissue components provide cushioning between the upper jaws similar to the function performed by the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint. Although less common, communication exists among the maxillary, spinaethmoidal, and ethmaline sinuses through the narrow opening formed by the infraorbital foramen.
Otolaryngology: Head and Neck Surgery: Nasal Disorders | University of Rochester School of Medicine
Functional vs Structural Changes Associated With Allergies
Allergic rhinitis is characterized by inflammation of the respiratory tract due to allergic exposure to environmental substances. Unlike infectious rhinorrhea associated with acute URI, rhinoconjunctivitis, or cough/phlegm production related to postnasal drip syndrome, the cause of allergic rhinitsis remains unknown. However, allergies are thought to arise as a result of hypersensitivity reactions following immunologic activation upon repeated exposure to allergens such as pollen grains, animal dander, dust mites, mold spores, fungal spores, certain foods, drugs, and chemicals. Common manifestations include sneezing, wheeze, itching, rash, hives, urticaria, asthma attacks, shortness of breath, chest tightness, coughing fits, and difficulty breathing. Other possible complications may include bronchospasm, hypotension, arrhythmias, dyspnea, syncope, cyanosis.
